Coder A.A7: GDPR consent is required for including subscriber personal data in telephone directories published by third-party providers, and such consent may be given to the operator or any directory provider.
Coder A.A8: Article 12(2) Directive 2002/58, Article 2(f) Directive 2002/58, Article 95 GDPR, Article 4(11) GDPR, Article 6(1)(a) GDPR
Coder A.A13: Article 4(11) of the GDPR, which constitutes the provision applicable to the facts at issue in the main proceedings, defines the 'consent of the data subject' as requiring a 'freely given, specific, informed and unambiguous' indication of the data subject's wishes in the form of a statement or of 'a clear affirmative action' signifying agreement to the processing of personal data relating to him or her.
Coder A.A15: It follows from a contextual and systematic interpretation of Article 12 of Directive 2002/58 that the consent under Article 12(2) relates to the purpose of the publication of personal data in a public directory and not to the identity of any particular directory provider.
Coder A.A17: Article 1(1) of Directive 2002/58 provides, inter alia, for the harmonisation of the national provisions required to ensure an equivalent level of protection of fundamental rights and freedoms, and in particular the right to privacy and confidentiality, with regard to the processing of personal data in the electronic communications sector.
Coder A.A23: It follows that such consent is necessary in order for the personal data relating to the subscriber of a telephone service operator to be included in directories.
Coder A.A25: As the Court has already held, such prior information gives the subscriber concerned the opportunity to give consent to the publication of his or her personal data in public directories, such consent being necessary for the purposes of such a publication.
Coder A.A33: Confirms that GDPR-standard consent is required for directory inclusion, strengthening subscriber control over personal data publication.

Coder A (Copy).A7: GDPR consent is required for including subscriber personal data in telephone directories published by third-party providers, and such consent may be given to the operator or any directory provider.
Coder A (Copy).A8: Article 12(2) Directive 2002/58, Article 2(f) Directive 2002/58, Article 95 GDPR, Article 4(11) GDPR, Article 6(1)(a) GDPR
Coder A (Copy).A13: Article 4(11) of the GDPR, which constitutes the provision applicable to the facts at issue in the main proceedings, defines the 'consent of the data subject' as requiring a 'freely given, specific, informed and unambiguous' indication of the data subject's wishes in the form of a statement or of 'a clear affirmative action' signifying agreement to the processing of personal data relating to him or her.
Coder A (Copy).A15: It follows from a contextual and systematic interpretation of Article 12 of Directive 2002/58 that the consent under Article 12(2) relates to the purpose of the publication of personal data in a public directory and not to the identity of any particular directory provider.
Coder A (Copy).A17: Article 1(1) of Directive 2002/58 provides, inter alia, for the harmonisation of the national provisions required to ensure an equivalent level of protection of fundamental rights and freedoms, and in particular the right to privacy and confidentiality, with regard to the processing of personal data in the electronic communications sector.
Coder A (Copy).A23: It follows that such consent is necessary in order for the personal data relating to the subscriber of a telephone service operator to be included in directories.
Coder A (Copy).A25: As the Court has already held, such prior information gives the subscriber concerned the opportunity to give consent to the publication of his or her personal data in public directories, such consent being necessary for the purposes of such a publication.
Coder A (Copy).A33: Confirms that GDPR-standard consent is required for directory inclusion, strengthening subscriber control over personal data publication.

Coder A.A7: A subscriber's request to withdraw personal data from telephone directories constitutes exercise of the right to erasure under Article 17 GDPR.
Coder A.A8: Article 17 GDPR, Article 12(2) Directive 2002/58, Article 6(1)(a) GDPR, Article 7(3) GDPR, Article 16 GDPR, Article 95 GDPR
Coder A.A13: Under the second sentence of Article 12(2) of Directive 2002/58, subscribers must have, inter alia, the opportunity to have the personal data relating to them withdrawn from public directories.
Coder A.A15: However, the grant of such an opportunity to subscribers does not constitute, as regards the providers of directories, a specific obligation, within the meaning of Article 95 of the GDPR, which would make it possible to exclude the application of the relevant provisions of that regulation.
Coder A.A17: Directive 2002/58 does not contain any indications as to the modalities, implementation and consequences of requests to obtain the withdrawal of personal data.
Coder A.A23: It follows from Article 17(1)(b) and (d) of the GDPR that the data subject is to have the right to obtain from the controller the erasure of personal data concerning him or her and that the controller is to have the obligation to erase those data without undue delay.
Coder A.A33: Classifies withdrawal requests as erasure rights under Article 17 GDPR, giving subscribers stronger legal protection than mere rectification.

Coder A (Copy).A7: A subscriber's request to withdraw personal data from telephone directories constitutes exercise of the right to erasure under Article 17 GDPR.
Coder A (Copy).A8: Article 17 GDPR, Article 12(2) Directive 2002/58, Article 6(1)(a) GDPR, Article 7(3) GDPR, Article 16 GDPR, Article 95 GDPR
Coder A (Copy).A13: Under the second sentence of Article 12(2) of Directive 2002/58, subscribers must have, inter alia, the opportunity to have the personal data relating to them withdrawn from public directories.
Coder A (Copy).A15: However, the grant of such an opportunity to subscribers does not constitute, as regards the providers of directories, a specific obligation, within the meaning of Article 95 of the GDPR, which would make it possible to exclude the application of the relevant provisions of that regulation.
Coder A (Copy).A17: Directive 2002/58 does not contain any indications as to the modalities, implementation and consequences of requests to obtain the withdrawal of personal data.
Coder A (Copy).A23: It follows from Article 17(1)(b) and (d) of the GDPR that the data subject is to have the right to obtain from the controller the erasure of personal data concerning him or her and that the controller is to have the obligation to erase those data without undue delay.
Coder A (Copy).A33: Classifies withdrawal requests as erasure rights under Article 17 GDPR, giving subscribers stronger legal protection than mere rectification.

Coder A.A7: A DPA may require directory providers to take measures to inform third-party controllers (operators and other directory providers) of a subscriber's consent withdrawal.
Coder A.A8: Article 5(2) GDPR, Article 24 GDPR, Article 19 GDPR, Article 7(3) GDPR, Article 12(2) GDPR, Article 6(1)(a) GDPR
Coder A.A13: Article 24 of the GDPR, that provision requires that, taking into account the nature, scope, context and purposes of processing, the controller implement appropriate technical and organisational measures to ensure and to be able to demonstrate that processing is performed in accordance with that regulation.
Coder A.A15: It follows from the general obligations laid down in Article 5(2) and Article 24 of the GDPR, read in conjunction with Article 19 thereof, that a controller of personal data, such as Proximus, must, by means of appropriate technical and organisational measures, inform the other providers of directories that have received such data from it of the withdrawal of the data subject's consent addressed to it.
Coder A.A17: In order to ensure the effectiveness of the right of the data subject to withdraw his or her consent provided for in Article 7(3) of the GDPR and to ensure that the data subject's consent is strictly linked to the purpose for which it was given, the controller to which the data subject has notified the withdrawal of his or her consent to the processing of his or her personal data is in fact required to communicate that withdrawal to any person who has forwarded those data to it and to the person to whom it has, in turn, forwarded those data.
Coder A.A23: Article 5(2) and Article 24 of the GDPR impose general accountability and compliance requirements upon controllers of personal data.
Coder A.A28: Such an approach would thus be contrary to Article 7(3) of the GDPR, which provides that it must be as easy to withdraw, as to give, consent to the processing of personal data.
Coder A.A33: Imposes chain notification obligations on controllers to facilitate consent withdrawal, making it easier for subscribers to exercise their rights.

Coder A (Copy).A7: A DPA may require directory providers to take measures to inform third-party controllers (operators and other directory providers) of a subscriber's consent withdrawal.
Coder A (Copy).A8: Article 5(2) GDPR, Article 24 GDPR, Article 19 GDPR, Article 7(3) GDPR, Article 12(2) GDPR, Article 6(1)(a) GDPR
Coder A (Copy).A13: Article 24 of the GDPR, that provision requires that, taking into account the nature, scope, context and purposes of processing, the controller implement appropriate technical and organisational measures to ensure and to be able to demonstrate that processing is performed in accordance with that regulation.
Coder A (Copy).A15: It follows from the general obligations laid down in Article 5(2) and Article 24 of the GDPR, read in conjunction with Article 19 thereof, that a controller of personal data, such as Proximus, must, by means of appropriate technical and organisational measures, inform the other providers of directories that have received such data from it of the withdrawal of the data subject's consent addressed to it.
Coder A (Copy).A17: In order to ensure the effectiveness of the right of the data subject to withdraw his or her consent provided for in Article 7(3) of the GDPR and to ensure that the data subject's consent is strictly linked to the purpose for which it was given, the controller to which the data subject has notified the withdrawal of his or her consent to the processing of his or her personal data is in fact required to communicate that withdrawal to any person who has forwarded those data to it and to the person to whom it has, in turn, forwarded those data.
Coder A (Copy).A23: Article 5(2) and Article 24 of the GDPR impose general accountability and compliance requirements upon controllers of personal data.
Coder A (Copy).A28: Such an approach would thus be contrary to Article 7(3) of the GDPR, which provides that it must be as easy to withdraw, as to give, consent to the processing of personal data.
Coder A (Copy).A33: Imposes chain notification obligations on controllers to facilitate consent withdrawal, making it easier for subscribers to exercise their rights.

Coder A.A7: A DPA may order directory providers to take reasonable steps to inform search engines of erasure requests from subscribers.
Coder A.A13: Article 17(2) of the GDPR imposes the obligation on the controller which has made the personal data public, taking account of available technology and the cost of implementation, to take reasonable steps, including technical measures, to inform controllers which are processing the personal data that the data subject has requested the erasure by such controllers of any links to, or copy or replication of, those personal data.
Coder A.A17: As is apparent from recital 66 of the GDPR, the objective of that obligation is to strengthen the right to be forgotten in the online environment, and therefore specifically applies to information made available on the internet by search engine providers that process data published online.
Coder A.A23: In circumstances such as those at issue in the main proceedings, it must be concluded that a controller such as Proximus is required, under Article 17(2) of the GDPR, to ensure that reasonable steps are taken to inform search engine providers of the request addressed to it by the subscriber of a telephone service operator for erasure of his or her personal data.
Coder A.A25: In accordance with settled case-law, the activity of a search engine consisting in finding information published or placed on the internet by third parties, indexing it automatically, storing it temporarily and, finally, making it available to internet users according to a particular order of preference must be classified as 'processing' of personal data within the meaning of Article 4(2) of the GDPR when that information contains personal data.
Coder A.A33: Extends directory providers' obligations to include notifying search engines, strengthening the right to be forgotten in the online environment.

Coder A (Copy).A7: A DPA may order directory providers to take reasonable steps to inform search engines of erasure requests from subscribers.
Coder A (Copy).A13: Article 17(2) of the GDPR imposes the obligation on the controller which has made the personal data public, taking account of available technology and the cost of implementation, to take reasonable steps, including technical measures, to inform controllers which are processing the personal data that the data subject has requested the erasure by such controllers of any links to, or copy or replication of, those personal data.
Coder A (Copy).A17: As is apparent from recital 66 of the GDPR, the objective of that obligation is to strengthen the right to be forgotten in the online environment, and therefore specifically applies to information made available on the internet by search engine providers that process data published online.
Coder A (Copy).A23: In circumstances such as those at issue in the main proceedings, it must be concluded that a controller such as Proximus is required, under Article 17(2) of the GDPR, to ensure that reasonable steps are taken to inform search engine providers of the request addressed to it by the subscriber of a telephone service operator for erasure of his or her personal data.
Coder A (Copy).A25: In accordance with settled case-law, the activity of a search engine consisting in finding information published or placed on the internet by third parties, indexing it automatically, storing it temporarily and, finally, making it available to internet users according to a particular order of preference must be classified as 'processing' of personal data within the meaning of Article 4(2) of the GDPR when that information contains personal data.
Coder A (Copy).A33: Extends directory providers' obligations to include notifying search engines, strengthening the right to be forgotten in the online environment.
